docs.lead_paragraph: A half-dozen or so teams will open the season tomorrow without a designated closer in their bullpen. In some cases, as with the St. Louis Cardinals and the Chicago Cubs, the closer is injured. In others, as with the Montreal Expos and the Tampa Bay Devils Rays, the teams simply don't have one relief pitcher who the manager feels can handle the closing job. In none of these cases will the manager use the ''closer by committee'' by choice. There is, on the other hand, one team that will use the system by design. Except the Boston Red Sox eschew the ''closer by committee'' label. They view their bullpen plan more like mix and match.
docs.abstract: Some people are skeptical of Boston Red Sox plan to use group of relievers rather than single closer; say only reason for using such a system is that team does not want to spend money to get dominant closer (M)

headline.main: Boston's Bullpen Plan Is Risky by Any Name

docs.lead_paragraph: From Arizona to Florida, all across the spring training landscape, front-office officials, managers, scouts and players agree on one thing: it's not steroids, not ephedra, not basebrawls. They agree that the Boston Red Sox made a huge mistake in keeping Casey Fossum and not trading him for Bartolo Colón. As a result of the decision not to make that swap, Fossum, a 25-year-old left-hander, will pitch this season with a spotlight on his arm and a target on his back.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox, faulted by many for not trading young pitcher Casey Fossum for pitcher Bartolo Colon, look to Fossum with high expectations for good season on starting rotation; photos (M)

headline.main: Fossum Out to Prove He's a Keeper

docs.lead_paragraph: The scoreboard at Fenway Park tonight bore a simple message. ''At bat, Number 9, batting .406.'' No Red Sox fan could misunderstand the meaning. It was a tribute to Ted Williams, the last batter to hit over .400, hitting .406 in 1941.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox teammates and fans honor Ted Williams on day after his death at age 83, remembering man who became Boston icon and last .400 hitter; photo (M)

headline.main: Boston Tips Its Cap on the Day the Legend Dies

docs.lead_paragraph: AT a baseball dinner some years ago, Ted Williams kept squinting at his notes as he spoke, but at the lectern now, Joe DiMaggio put on glasses. ''That's what I needed,'' Williams said. ''My glasses.''
docs.abstract: Dave Anderson Sports of The Times column discusses legacy of Boston Red Sox player Ted Williams, whose death at 83 years old ignites look back at astonishing career of 'last .400 hitter'; photo (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; For Ted, The Eyes Had It

docs.lead_paragraph: Frustrated by a poor outing against the Oakland Athletics on Tuesday night, Boston's Bret Saberhagen said today that he had decided to retire at the end of the season.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox pitcher Bret Saberhagen announces retirement after season (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVER since the Fleet Center replaced the Boston Garden, basketball has never been the same where, more than 200 years ago, America's jockey, Paul Revere, yelled, ''The British are coming.'' According to most of New England's current colonists, the Fleet Center has no charm. Of course, the Celtics have no players and the Bruins aren't much better, but in Boston, charm is more important than a modern look. Something, anything, can be new in Boston, but ideally, it somehow should look as old as the Old North Church.
docs.abstract: Dave Anderson Sports of The Times column discusses plans to build new Fenway Park for Boston Red Sox; photo (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; A New Fenway Park Offers Yanks a Lesson

docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty-four hours after his club's challengers completed a whirlwind of trading activity, Dan Duquette sat in a room at the Otesaga Hotel in Cooperstown, N.Y., yesterday. "The Red Sox are up here looking for some complete-game pitchers," the Boston general manager, in town for today's Hall of Fame induction ceremonies, said jokingly by telephone. "They haven't been able to find them on the trade market so they're looking up in Cooperstown."

headline.main: Red Sox, In First, Playing Catch-Up

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox have offered their former catcher CARLTON FISK a coaching job within the organization. Fisk, who grew up in New Hampshire and now lives in a Chicago suburb, and his agent, JACK SANDS, met this week with the Red Sox owner, JOHN HARRINGTON, and General Manager DAN DUQUETTE to discuss a coaching position. Duquette did not say whether the job involves coaching in the minor leagues or with Boston.

headline.main: Fisk Offered a Coaching Job by Red Sox

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox, who had the worst save percentage in the American League last season, signed free-agent relief pitcher Jeff Russell to a one-year deal yesterday and hope to make him their stopper. Russell, a 31-year-old right-hander traded from Texas to Oakland last August, made eight scoreless relief appearances for the Athletics in their drive for the American League West title last season.
